thread.title: Trump: Media afraid to show 'outpouring of love' for me
thread.title_full: Trump: Media afraid to show 'outpouring of love' for me | Washington Examiner

author: Gabby Morrongiello
title: Trump: Media afraid to show 'outpouring of love' for me
text:
Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump urged a handful of cameramen Monday to show the American people, and his wife, the "outpouring of love" he's receiving on the campaign trail.
"I tell you, I go home and my wife sees me and she goes 'Oh, did you have many people?''' the outspoken billionaire told a crowded room of about 5,000 supporters during a campaign rally in Anderson, S.C.
Trump accused the media of refusing to show the turnout at his campaign events, often in the thousands, because they don't want to reveal the support he's receiving.
Related Story: http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/article/2574118/ "It's the message," he said Monday. "They have the cameras here. Look, live cameras — CNN, Fox, MSNBC. They have live cameras, but they don't ever scan the room because if they scan the room what you'll see is this kind of outpouring of love."
  GOP: Obama broke his promise on Iran "The Iran nuclear deal solves a specific problem" regarding Iran's nukes, not its aggression, Obama said.
By Charles Hoskinson • 10/19/15 7:31 PM "They don't want to show that," he added, before pointing directly at media personnel present at the event.
"Go ahead guys, scan the room. We've got time," Trump said. A local television station live-streaming the event obeyed, zooming out to capture the crowd.
The leading GOP candidate later said he's been most surprised by the media throughout his bid for the presidency.
"A tremendous portion of the media — they're so dishonest," Trump said.
He offered an anecdote to substantiate his claims. "We had 5,000 people at an event in New Hampshire and this was in a small auditorium," he said. And then Hillary [Clinton], she was a few miles, literally, up the road and she had 250 people people."
Also from the Washington Examiner A frankly Republican history of American politics The Democratic party is 'a sad place, young man, for you to put your young life into.'
By Michael Barone • 10/19/15 7:19 PM "Then I come back and the next day she's on the front page of the New York Times and I'm saying what about me?" he added.
"But it doesn't matter," Trump conceded. "We understand what's happening. It's a movement."
Trump leads the Washington Examiner's presidential power rankings. He earned 25 percent support in the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll of Republican voters.
